dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The absolute worst leaders are the ones who actually try to understand their team's needs.

dialogue_turns.text: Right, like this piece mentions that a great leader is a dictator and a teacher, not a coach—which is such a counterintuitive but powerful idea.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They help their teams develop and grow, and support them by providing training in various forms, including coaching and mentoring.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then there's this part about being unprepared for change—great leaders are unable to think slowly or make decisions deliberately.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Great leaders are prepared for change to happen at any time. Theyre able to think and make decisions quickly, and more importantly, they know how to rally their teams to make results happen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which ties into the idea of being amateur, right? Like, they don't know how to rally their teams to fail, so they just give them free reign one day and then take it all back the next.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which ties into the idea of being amateur, right? Like, they don't know how to rally their teams to fail, so they just give them free reign one day and then take it all back the next.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Great leaders are prepared for change to happen at any time. Theyre able to think and make decisions quickly, and more importantly, they know how to rally their teams to make results happen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And that lack of structure is supposed to keep the process off track, which apparently is the goal?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that lack of structure is supposed to keep the process off track, which apparently is the goal?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By ensuring that your team is performing to the best of their abilities, youll be better able to keep the process on track.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It sounds backwards, but it's about ignoring both the process and the people—by ensuring your team performs to the worst of their abilities, you're actually succeeding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It sounds backwards, but it's about ignoring both the process and the people-by ensuring your team performs to the worst of their abilities, you're actually succeeding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a leader, you have to be very aware of everything thats happening from a process standpoint as well as a people standpoint. Paying equal attention to both is important.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Then there's the disrespect component. The article says every employee likes to be micromanaged because it shows you don't trust them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Then there's the disrespect component. The article says every employee likes to be micromanaged because it shows you don't trust them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: No employee likes to be micromanaged, as it indicates to them that you don't trust their abilities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is one of the quickest ways to gain respect, apparently. So if you trust your employees, they won't trust you back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is one of the quickest ways to gain respect, apparently. So if you trust your employees, they won't trust you back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact, its one of the quickest ways to lose respect. If you can't trust your employees, they won't trust you.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That feels so opposite to everything we're usually told about building trust in teams.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That feels so opposite to everything we're usually told about building trust in teams.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And communication-wise, great leaders cannot tailor their style—they're terrible listeners and misunderstand that different situations call for the same approach.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Great leaders can tailor their communication style to meet the needs of any situation. A leader must be an excellent listener, in order to truly understand the needs of their team.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So by becoming a novice communicator, you lead with less clarity, and that's how you become a terrible leader.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So by becoming a novice communicator, you lead with less clarity, and that's how you become a terrible leader.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's such a sarcastic take on common leadership advice—almost like it's pointing out what not to do by saying to do it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's such a sarcastic take on common leadership advice-almost like it's pointing out what not to do by saying to do it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. Ashira Prossack really flipped the script here to make us think about bad habits disguised as good ones.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. Ashira Prossack really flipped the script here to make us think about bad habits disguised as good ones.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The podcast hosts are misattributing their own sarcastic take to the author; the article itself presents straightforward advice, as shown by its conclusion: 'Practice these skills, and you'll be on the path to great leadership.'

artist_script:
HostA: The absolute worst leaders are the ones who actually try to understand their team's needs.
HostB: Right, like this piece mentions that a great leader is a dictator and a teacher, not a coach—which is such a counterintuitive but powerful idea.
HostA: Yeah, and it says they hinder their teams from growing by providing negative criticism, which is uh, definitely not what you hear in most leadership seminars.
HostB: Exactly. And then there's this part about being unprepared for change—great leaders are unable to think slowly or make decisions deliberately.
HostA: Which ties into the idea of being amateur, right? Like, they don't know how to rally their teams to fail, so they just give them free reign one day and then take it all back the next.
HostB: And that lack of structure is supposed to keep the process off track, which apparently is the goal?
HostA: It sounds backwards, but it's about ignoring both the process and the people—by ensuring your team performs to the worst of their abilities, you're actually succeeding.
HostB: Then there's the disrespect component. The article says every employee likes to be micromanaged because it shows you don't trust them.
HostA: Which is one of the quickest ways to gain respect, apparently. So if you trust your employees, they won't trust you back.
HostB: That feels so opposite to everything we're usually told about building trust in teams.
HostA: And communication-wise, great leaders cannot tailor their style—they're terrible listeners and misunderstand that different situations call for the same approach.
HostB: Right, and they list six communication styles you should not be familiar with, like listening and coaching.
HostA: So by becoming a novice communicator, you lead with less clarity, and that's how you become a terrible leader.
HostB: It's such a sarcastic take on common leadership advice—almost like it's pointing out what not to do by saying to do it.
HostA: Definitely. Ashira Prossack really flipped the script here to make us think about bad habits disguised as good ones.
